Award.AwardTitle: What Stabilizes Population Dynamics in Nature? A New Framework for Quantifying the in situ Strength and Nonlinearity of Species Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental question in ecology is how interactions among species (e.g. predator-prey) cause some species to exhibit cyclic population fluctuations over time while for other species they do not. An understanding of these mechanisms is necessary in order to forecast how species and their ecosystems will respond to environmental perturbations, including habitat loss and climate change. This research project will develop new methods and statistical analyses that will be applied to stream communities of the Pacific Northwest. The investigators will test hypotheses regarding when species populations will cycle in abundance. Current theory can explain only the most simplistic case of specialist predator species that feed on only one or a few prey species. However, most species in nature are generalists embedded in complex networks of species interactions. This limitation is widely acknowledged as a significant problem in the development of resource management and conservation practices. This work promises to advance general ecological theory and resolve a long standing puzzle concerning stability of predator-prey interactions in nature. Results of this project will improve our ability to forecast species responses to environmental disturbances, which is important in wildlife management and conservation. This project also will support the mentoring, and research training of undergraduate and graduate students, and a postdoctoral researcher. Broader involvement with Oregon's local communities will be achieved through an extensive collaboration with Oregon State University's elementary school partnership program, which provides science and math enrichment for elementary school students and professional development for their teachers in order to increase the number of underrepresented and educationally underserved students that go on to pursue careers in science, math, health, engineering, and education.

This research will develop a new class of observational methods for estimating the strength of predator-prey interactions in species-rich systems. Observational and experimental implementations of the approach in stream communities of the Andrews Experimental Forest Long Term Ecological Research site will be used to quantitatively compare the degree to which prey-dependent, consumer-dependent and adaptive-foraging processes contribute to empirical levels of interaction nonlinearity. Empirically-derived insights will be integrated into abstracted mathematical models to develop general theory regarding the dynamics of specialist and generalist consumers. This research promises significant advances in our conceptual and applied understanding of the mechanisms by which predator-prey interactions regulate the dynamics of species-rich communities. The novel simplicity and broad applicability of the observational approach to be developed here promises a transformative new way to bridge mathematical theory and empirical data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A fundamental question in ecology is how the interactions between species influence the stability of population dynamics.  For example, why do the populations of some species exhibit cyclic fluctuations over time while those of other species do not.  Our understanding of the mechanisms underlying population stability predicates our ability to forecast how species and their ecosystems will respond to disturbances and other changes in their environment, including habitat deterioration and climate change.  Current understanding is rooted in the logistically-tractable study of specialist predator species that feed on only one or a few prey species.  However, most species in nature are generalists embedded in complex networks of species interactions.  This limitation in our understanding is widely acknowledged as a significant problem in the development of resource management and conservation practices.

In this project, we first succeeded in developing a statistically-rigorous new class of methods enabling the species interactions of generalist predators to be characterized and quantified in the context of their species-rich communities.  Our methods avoid the logistical, statistical and philosophical problems associated with prior methods such as manipulative experiments and time-series analysis.  We then successfully applied these methods in two primary contexts:

Our first primary application entailed a combination of extensive field- and lab-work focused on the generalist predator-prey interactions that comprise the complex food webs of western Oregon streams.  Our primary findings related to better understanding the factors that drive variation and change in interaction strengths -- both within and between different predator-prey species pairs and across space and through time -- in these seasonally dynamic systems.  We were able to quantify, for example, how interaction strengths in nature are driven by multiple simultaneous factors, thereby underscoring the ways in which simplified experiments may be leading to biased inferences about the structure and dynamics of species-rich food webs.

Our second primary application entailed an integration of data (which we extracted from the existing literature) and new mathematical theory (which we developed as part of this project) focused on understanding the mechanisms by which species interaction strengths actually determine the stability of predatory-prey population dynamics.  Together, our theory and data synthesis contradict the conventional understanding of what causes predator-prey populations to cycle and evidence that ongoing environmental changes around the globe are weakening the extent to which predators control the abundance of their prey, are increasing the extinction risk of predator populations, and are decreasing the propensity of predator-prey populations to exhibit oscillations in their abundance.

These, and a variety of associated products motivated and enabled by the award, have therefore advanced both our conceptual and applied understanding of the mechanisms by which species interactions regulate community dynamics, thereby aiding our ability to forecast how species and their ecosystems are responding to disturbances and other changes in their environment.

In the process, the project directly supported two postdocs (one went on to become a Humboldt Fellow and the other is now an Assistant Professor), two graduate students, five research associates and technicians, 2 undergraduate researchers, 8 undergraduate research assistants, and over 17 undergraduate volunteers, many of whom represented minority groups who remain underserved within the sciences in general and within ecology in particular.

Broader involvement with Oregon's local communities was successfully achieved through an extensive collaboration with Oregon State University's Science Math Investigative Learning Experience (SMILE) university-school partnership program.  This state-wide program provides science and math enrichment for elementary school students and professional development for their teachers in order to increase the number of underrepresented and educationally underserved students that go on to pursue careers in science, math, health, engineering, and education.  The SMILE after-school clubs we supported, contributed curriculum and materials to, and whose teachers we provided professional development training to, reached approximately ~200 students from 10 high-needs elementary schools in each year of our project.  (The majority of these students represented females from a self-described underrepresented minority of low-income status and would be their family's first-generation going to college.)
